item.title: IOOF says it has no systemic issues as it unveils modest $10m compensation bill - The Australian Financial Review
item.description:
IOOF says it has no systemic issues as it unveils modest $10m compensation bill  The Australian Financial Review

IOOF revealed it will pay some $500000 in compensation for charging dead people as analysts questioned its overall bill for "fee for no *service*".

item.description:
Markets Live: IOOF falls further, ASX trades higher  The Sydney Morning Herald

IOOF Holdings has continued to fall through the day as investors head for the exits while the broader market is trading firmly higher.

item.title: IOOF cops royal drubbing - The Australian
item.description:
IOOF cops royal drubbing  The Australian

IOOF’s very survival is now in question even if APRA’s unprecedented royal commission-inspired regulatory attack represents what the industry sees as low hanging fruit. In his 21-year acquisition-fuelled expansion, IOOF boss Chris Kelaher has established a reputation cemented in his royal commission appearance as being arrogant and on the low end of the corporate governance curve. Like that other easy target, AMP, IOOF stands at the centre of the severely tarnished wealth management sector at the very time it was set to prosper because the banks were forced sellers. Both IOOF and AMP were o...

item.title: Financial regulator seeks to disqualify IOOF directors and top executives - The Guardian
item.description:
Financial regulator seeks to disqualify IOOF directors and top executives  The Guardian

The financial regulator is seeking to disqualify the directors and senior executives of one of Australia’s biggest wealth managers, IOOF Investment Management, for failing to act in the best interests of superannuation members. The startling move on Friday – which prompted the firm’s shares to crash 36% – comes after the IOOF managing director, Chris Kelaher, gave shocking evidence to the banking royal commission in August about its treatment of super members. At one point, Kelaher defended IOOF’s decision to compensate investors in a cash management trust, using their own money, for a mist...

item.title: IOOF plunges $800m as APRA moves to disqualify top execs - ABC News
item.description:
IOOF plunges $800m as APRA moves to disqualify top execs  ABC News

Australia's financial regulator has taken action against superannuation giant IOOF in the Federal Court and is trying to disqualify its top executives from managing people's retirement savings. Its managing director Chris Kelaher, along with four senior executives, failed to act in the best interests of superannuation members, the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA) alleges. This led to IOOF's share price plunging 31.7 per cent to $4.90 at 11:45am (AEDT), its lowest value in 18 years. In dollar terms, $800 million was wiped off the company's market value in just a few hours. I...

item.title: Australia’s IOOF drops as banking regulator targets top executives - Financial Times
item.description:
Australia’s IOOF drops as banking regulator targets top executives  Financial Times

Australia’s banking regulator said on Friday it was seeking to disqualify five senior executives and directors of IOOF Holdings, one of the country’s biggest wealth managers, for failing to act in the best interests of pension fund members. The legal action initiated by the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority caused a sharp sell-off in IOOF shares, which fell as much as 28 per cent to A$5.15 about an hour after opening on the ASX. ANZ Bank, which is selling part of its wealth division to IOOF for A$1bn, said it was assessing its “options” following Apra’s intervention, which marks a ...

item.title: Australia’s IOOF drops 28% as regulator targets top executives - Financial Times
item.description:
Australia’s IOOF drops 28% as regulator targets top executives  Financial Times

Australia’s banking regulator said on Friday it is seeking to disqualify five senior executives and directors of IOOF Holdings, including the wealth managers’ managing director and chairman, for failing to act in the best interests of pension fund members. The legal action initiated by the Australian Prudential Regulatory Authority (Apra) caused a sharp sell off in IOOF shares, which were down by 28 per cent to A$5.15 ($3.72) about an hour after opening on the ASX. ANZ Bank, which is selling part of its wealth division to IOOF for A$1bn, said it was assessing its “options” following Apra’s ...

item.title: Class action against IOOF quashed - The Australian
item.description:
Class action against IOOF quashed  The Australian

Maurice Blackburn Lawyers had planned to pursue a class action on behalf of tens of thousands of IOOF shareholders over the company’s handling of allegations of corporate misconduct.

IOOF shares dropped 13 per cent in June 2015 when allegations were raised by the media of problems with the compliance culture of its research team. The company said the issues had been dealt with appropriately at the time, but Maurice Blackburn claimed IOOF breached its continuous disclosure obligations by not previously informing the market of the issues.

The Victorian Supreme Court on Frid...

item.title: IOOF sees potential in ANZ wealth - The Australian
item.description:
IOOF sees potential in ANZ wealth  The Australian

“The way it is presented, we would be a prime buyer if it plays out the way it has been stated,” Mr Kelaher said in an interview with The Australian.

“We have a number of different opportunities we are looking at. Prima facie, it presents very attractively. We are the most successful purchaser in this space. Theoretically it is on all fours with what we do.”

IOOF is now one of the biggest independent wealth advisers in Australia following a series of acquisitions in recent years, including last year’s $670 million takeover of the Shadforth Financial Group.

It ...

item.title: Upbeat IOOF on hunt for deals - The Australian
item.description:
Upbeat IOOF on hunt for deals  The Australian

The wealth management firm saw net inflows in the full year surge 156 per cent to $4.6 billion, including $976 million from 33 new advisers, as it reaps the benefits of advisers deserting the big banks. Labelling it a “very pleasing result”, IOOF managing director Chris Kelaher said it showed the company could deliver growth organically as well as through M&A. “This (result) is confirmation that building out a more organic profile is paying dividends and we’ve balanced the business on both sides,” Mr Kelaher told The Australian. “Our outlook going forward is very encouraging — we’re attract...

item.title: Results season: Transurban earnings soar, while IOOF profit drops - ABC News
item.description:
Results season: Transurban earnings soar, while IOOF profit drops  ABC News

Australia's biggest toll road operator Transurban has reported an almost 10-fold increase in full year profit, but it still has left investors feeling short changed. Key points: - Transurban toll revenues up 10.6pc on 4 higher traffic volumes - Shares sold off aggressively despite 850pc increas in net profit - IOOF shares bounce despite profit slump as cost cutting impresses Transurban's net profit was up 850 per cent to $209 million, from $22 million the year before. While total revenue rose by 24 per cent to $2.7 billion, the major difference was the 2017 result was not weighed down by si...

item.title: IOOF’s hit as profit falls 45pc - The Australian
item.description:
IOOF’s hit as profit falls 45pc  The Australian

Chief executive Chris Kelaher remained upbeat in the face of the 45 per cent slide in interim profit, which dropped to $74.2 million for the six months to December. The hefty fall in statutory profit was largely a result of the prior year’s sale of IOOF’s Perennial business, which was passed off to Henderson Group. On an underlying basis, profit fell a more modest 17 per cent, with “market adversity” blamed as the main driver of the softer ­result. IOOF shares sank 8 per cent to $8.50 in the biggest one-day fall for the stock since a 2015 media report alleged frontrunning and misconduct in ...

item.title: IOOF lifts as inflows surge - The Australian
item.description:
IOOF lifts as inflows surge  The Australian

The $4.6 billion of net inflows included $976m from 33 new advisers joining the firm, and drove funds under management, administration and advice (FUMA) to $115bn. “During the year, we achieved outstanding funds growth, exceptional cost control and our underlying performance metrics are on an upward trajectory,” managing director Christopher Kelaher said. “Our adviser numbers are growing, which appears to be counter to industry trend. Flagship platform net inflows of $1.2bn demonstrate that service excellence results in significantly increased flows. The drop in statutory net profit include...

item.title: IOOF eyes flows as profit sinks - The Australian
item.description:
IOOF eyes flows as profit sinks  The Australian

IOOF (IFL) on Wednesday booked an interim profit of $74.2 million for the six months through December, which was down 45 per cent year-on-year. The slide in profit was mainly due to the prior year’s $72m sale of IOOF’s Perennial business, which was passed off to Henderson Group. The group, which now manages around $110 billion in funds, said its underlying profit was down a more modest 17 per cent. It came against a 2 per cent slide in revenue to $457.4m. But a healthy lift in net flows of $1.4bn over the six months was proof of the resilience of the IOOF brand, according to chief executive...

item.title: IOOF to poach more advisers - The Australian
item.description:
IOOF to poach more advisers  The Australian

IOOF recorded a nearly 300 per cent increase in net fund flows for the three months through March, with positive net flows of $998 million. Managing director Chris Kelaher said strong fund flows would continue after a cohort of about 50 advisers joined, bringing with them $154m. Mr Kelaher declined to disclose where the advisers had come from, but said the company planned to encourage more recruits from large institutional rivals. “At the full year we’ll be absolute about clarity. The reason I can’t say is that there are potentially more advisers to come and I don’t want to jeopardise that ...

item.title: Big four in fees probe - The Australian
item.description:
Big four in fees probe  The Australian

Australia’s big four banks — Commonwealth Bank, ANZ, NAB and Westpac — are among financial institutions the corporate watchdog plans to investigate as part of a large-scale inquiry into widespread failure to tell advice customers what fees they were being charged or give them a chance to stop paying them. Spokesmen for the nation’s biggest bank, CBA, and third-largest, ANZ, said their institutions had confessed breaches of the requirements to the Australian Securities & Investments Commission. The CBA reported breaches to ASIC in December but has yet to update its systems to stop them conti...

item.title: Live: Banking royal commission super hearings continue - ABC News
item.description:
Live: Banking royal commission super hearings continue  ABC News

The banking royal commission is continuing its super hearings, with NAB set for a final grilling, while Australian Super and IOOF are slated to appear later today. External Link: Banking royal commission live blog

item.title: Analysis: Industry super funds sail through banking royal commission's spotlight - ABC News
item.description:
Analysis: Industry super funds sail through banking royal commission's spotlight  ABC News

By business reporter Daniel Ziffer With the 'service' customers got for the fee they paid, which one bank attempted to suggest, was for receiving marketing material? With a bank, asked for every document about the issue of 'fee for no service', handing over 31 documents by the royal commission's deadline. And then more than 3,000 just days before they're set to be examined? With a fund chief executive who isn't concerned by a regulator slamming its lax governance and finding shareholders' interests are favoured over customers, and begrudgingly making changes (not because they agree) simply ...

item.title: It’s simple: fees erode returns - The Australian
item.description:
It’s simple: fees erode returns  The Australian

One of the world’s top experts on superannuation has called out claims from the major banks and financial services giants AMP and IOOF that it is “factually incorrect” or “misleading” to use the officially audited data, which they are legally required to file with the regulator, to judge their ­performance. University of NSW Business School academic Kevin Liu, who earned his PhD investigating superannuation fund performance — and is a former internal researcher for banking and super watchdog the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority — said that the data was in fact the most accurate wa...

item.title: ‘If we can’t do better, leave’ - The Advertiser
item.description:
‘If we can’t do better, leave’  The Advertiser

THE new manager of some of Australia’s worst super funds has told hundreds of thousands of long-suffering account holders that if his company can’t do better they should leave. Australian financial services company IOOF is in the process of taking control of ANZ’s $47 billion worth of pensions and investments, including products widely regarded as the biggest duds on the market. Stockspot, which publishes the Fat Cat Funds Report, recently named ANZ as the fattest fund manager in the nation — for the fourth year running. Stockspot founder Chris Brycki is particularly critical of ANZ’s OnePa...

item.title: Catapult Wealth’s top stock picks - The Advertiser
item.description:
Catapult Wealth’s top stock picks  The Advertiser

Dulux Group (DLX) - BUY Dulux Group includes several market leading brands, including Dulux, British Paints, Berger, Selleys and others. Dulux is a quality business with a long history of growing its profit, dividend, and share price. With the home improvement market making up the majority of revenues the company is supported by a defensive earnings stream, and insulated from the more cyclical construction market. Solid results have pushed the share price higher over the last few months and some investors may want to wait on a more attractive entry point, but for investors with a long-time ...

item.title: ANZ poised to sell OnePath Pensions - The Australian
item.description:
ANZ poised to sell OnePath Pensions  The Australian

ANZ is selling its financial advice businesses to 'serial acquirer' IOOF Holdings for $975 million.

item.title: ANZ sells pensions and investments business for $765m - Financial Times
item.description:
ANZ sells pensions and investments business for $765m  Financial Times

ANZ Bank has sold its OnePath pensions and investments business to financial services company IOOF Holdings Limited for A$975m ($765.3m), continuing a trend towards banks exiting non-core operations. The Australian lender had initially flagged the sale of its entire wealth management business, which could be worth up to A$4bn, but said on Tuesday it had decided to separate the superannuation and insurance divisions and look for separate outcomes for both businesses. “The sale of our pensions and investments and aligned dealer groups businesses provides ANZ with greater flexibility to consid...
